case_name: Mannalal Jain v. State of Assam

facts.text: Writ petition No. 303 of 1960 filed by Mannalal Jain under Article 32 on October 17, 1960

anchor.surface_text: This writ petition by one Mannalal Jain was originally filed on October 17, 1960, and the order companyplained of was dated September 13, 1960.

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner, Kamrup Gauhati rejected petitioner's application for license for 1960 on September 13, 1960

anchor.surface_text: This was an order made by the Deputy Commissioner, Kamrup Gauhati, rejecting an application made by the petitioner for the grant of a license for the year 1960 for dealing in rice and paddy under the relevant provisions of the Assam Foodgrains Licensing and Control Order, 1960.

facts.text: Petition heard on February 2, 1961 and adjourned sine die because 1960 license period expired

anchor.surface_text: This writ petition was put up for hearing in this Court on February 2, 1961. The hearing was, however, adjourned sine die, because it was stated before us that the period of licence for 1960 had already expired

facts.text: Petitioner made fresh application for 1961 license on February 4, 1961

anchor.surface_text: A fresh application was accordingly made by the petitioner on February 4, 1961. But before that date a fresh Assam Foodgrains Licensing, and Control Order, 1961 was made by the Governor of Assam

facts.text: Assam Foodgrains Licensing and Control Order, 1961 made by Governor of Assam before February 4, 1961

anchor.surface_text: But before that date a fresh Assam Foodgrains Licensing, and Control Order, 1961 was made by the Governor of Assam and the application made by the Petitioner had to be dealt with under the new Order.

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner rejected petitioner's 1961 application on April 11, 1961

anchor.surface_text: On April II, 1961 an order was made rejecting the application of the petitioner. This order which is impugned before us was in these terms.

facts.text: Rejection reason: existing licenses in Mangaldai and Gauhati and quantity of foodgrains make further license superfluous

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the existing licenses in these areas Mangaldai and Gauhati , and the quantity of foodgrains available therein, any further license would be superfluous.

facts.text: Petitioner Mannalal Jain is Indian citizen carrying business in rice and paddy in Kamrup, Assam

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner states that he is an Indian citizen carrying on a business dealing in rice and paddy in the district of Kamrup in the State of Assam.

facts.text: Essential Commodities Act, 1955 enacted in 1955

anchor.surface_text: In 1955 was enacted the Essential Commodities Act, 1955 Act 10 of 1955 .

facts.text: Assam Foodgrains Licensing and Control Order, 1958 made by Assam Government

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of the powers companyferred by s. 3 of the said Act, read with a numberification by which the said powers were delegated by the Central Government to the Government of Assam, the latter Government made an Order called- the Assam Foodgrains Licensing and Control Order. 1958.

facts.text: Petitioner obtained license in 1958, expired December 31, 1958

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner states that he obtained such a license in 1958. This license expired on December 31, 1958.

facts.text: Dispute whether petitioner obtained license for 1959

anchor.surface_text: The case of the petitioner is that in 1959 also he carried on his business though there is some dispute as to whether he obtained a license for that year.

facts.text: Letter received by petitioner on November 26, 1959 from Deputy Director of Supply, Gauhati that license not renewed after Dec 31, 1959

anchor.surface_text: On November 26, 1959, the petitioner received a letter from the office of the Deputy Director of Supply, Gauhati, which said that his license would number be renewed after December 31, 1959.

facts.text: Government of Assam decided to give monopoly procurement of paddy to Assam Co-operative Apex Marketing Society Ltd. (respondent No. 6)

anchor.surface_text: This companymunication, it is stated, was the result of a decision taken by the Government of Assam on the advice of a body called the Food Advisory Council to give a right of monopoly procurement of paddy to a companyperative society in the district of Kamrup known as the Assam Co. operative Apex Marketing Society Ltd. respondent No. 6 before us .

facts.text: Assam Foodgrains Licensing and Control Order, 1960 came into force on January 5, 1960

anchor.surface_text: on January 5, 1960, the Assam Foodgrains Licensing and Control Order, 1960, came into force. This replaced the earlier Order of 1958.

facts.text: Petitioner applied for 1960 license on January 28, 1960

anchor.surface_text: On January 28, 1960 the petitioner made his application for a license for the year 1960.

facts.text: Application rejected on February 17, 1960 because monopoly to Co-operative Apex Marketing Society

anchor.surface_text: This application was rejected by an order dated February 17, 1960. The reason given for the rejection was in these terms You are hereby informed that as the Co- operative Apex Marketing Society has been given the right of monopoly purchase in the Kamrup district this year, your case. cannot be companysidered for issue of the license.

facts.text: High Court of Assam allowed writ petition against Feb 17, 1960 order, quashed it and directed consideration on merits under Clause 5

anchor.surface_text: Against-this order the petitioner moved the High Court of Assam by means of a writ petition under Art. 226, of the Constitution. The High Court allowed the petition mainly on the ground that the application, of the petitioner for a license for, the year 1960 was number companysidered on merits by the licensing authority in accordance with the provisions of el. 5 of the Assam Foodgrains Licensing and Control Order, 1960.

facts.text: Licensing authority made another rejection order on June 8, 1960

anchor.surface_text: On June 8, 1960 the licensing authority made another order refusing to grant a license to the petitioner. This order stated that as the Assam Co- operative Apex Marketing Society Ltd., had already been granted a license to deal in rice and paddy., with its branches spread all over the district,

facts.text: High Court set aside June 8, 1960 order on August 10, 1960 and directed independent consideration

anchor.surface_text: On August 10, 1960 the-High Court again set aside the order and directed the licensing authority to act independently of instructions received from the Government and, to apply its mind to the merits of the application and, decide it in accordance with the relevant provisions

facts.text: Licensing authority rejected application again on September 13, 1960 citing Clause 5(b) and co-op advantages

anchor.surface_text: On September 13, 1960 the licensing authority made another order, again rejecting the application of the petitioner. This order stated inter alia For the areas for which the application have been made the Assam Co-operative Apex Marketing Society Ltd., has earlier. applied for and has been granted license.

facts.text: Assam Foodgrains Licensing and Control Order, 1961 includes new clause 5(e): whether applicant is co-operative society

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary to read here cl. 5 of the Control Order, 1961. Matters to be taken into companysideration for granting a license.-In granting or refusing a license under this Order, the licensing authority shall, among. other matters, have regard to the following, namely-  a  the stock of foodgrains available in the locality for-which the license is required  b  the number of persons who have applied for and those who have been granted licenses in respect of the foodgrains under this Order in the locality  c  the business ordinarily carried on by the applicant  d  the past activities of the applicant as a licensee or business man firm and  e  whether the applicant is a companyperative society.

facts.text: High Court rejected contempt application on November 10, 1960

anchor.surface_text: To companyplete the statement of facts, it may perhaps be observed that on November 10, 1960, the High Court rejected the application for proceeding against the opposite, parties by way of companytempt, mainly on the ground. that the order made on September 13, 1960, was number before it.

facts.text: Private dealers completely excluded from licenses in 1961 in Assam

anchor.surface_text: The affidavits show that private dealers have been companypletely excluded. In the affidavit filed on behalf of respondent No. 1, it has been stated in para. 4 It is number denied that in the year 1961 licenses for the procurement of paddy have been issued to the companyperatives in all the paddy producing districts in Assam.

facts.text: Supreme Court quashes April 11, 1961 order and license to respondent No. 6, directs fresh consideration

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that the impugned order is bad as violating the rights of the petitioner guaranteed under Arts. 14 and 19 of the Constitution. We must, therefore, quash the order of the licensing authority dated April 11, 1961. We must also quash the order by which the licensing authority granted a licence in favour of respondent No. 6.
Under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: The first ground of attack is that sub-cl. e of cl.5 of the Control Order, 1961 is ultra vires,because it goes beyond the powers granted to the State Government under s. 3 read with S. 5 of the Essential Commodities Act, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: it violated the petitioners rights under Arts. 14 and 19 of the Constitution. He is accordingly entitled. to come. to this Court under Art. 32 of the Constitution to have the order quashed.

holdings.text: Clause 5 of the Control Order, 1961 does not provide for a monopoly in favour of co-operative societies but merely enumerates matters including preference to co-operatives in certain circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that cl. 5 of the Control Order, 1961 does not provide for a monopoly in favour of cooperative societies. The clause enumerates five matters and states that the licensing authority shall have regard to those matters in granting or refusing a license.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Text of cl.5 requires regard to listed matters 'among other matters'; sub-cl.(e) enables preference but not exclusion of all others or monopoly creation.

holdings.text: Sub-clause (e) of clause 5 of the Control Order, 1961 is intra vires and within powers under s.3 of Essential Commodities Act, 1955 as it relates to objects of maintaining supplies and equitable distribution.

anchor.surface_text: Can it be said that the fifth matter mentioned in sub-cl. e viz., whether the applicant is a co operative society is completely unrelated to those two objects? We are unable to say that it is.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Co-operatives have better facilities for procurement, assured prices to farmers, eliminate middlemen; aligns with National Development Council policy and s.3 objects.

holdings.text: Sub-clause (e) satisfies reasonable classification under Art.14 as it has rational relation to legislative objects but does not authorize class legislation or monopoly.

anchor.surface_text: The preference given has a reasonable relation to the objects of the legislation set out in s. 3 of the Act therefore, sub-cl. e of cl. 5 of the Control Order, 1961, cannot be held to be bad on the ground of class legislation

holdings.reasoning_summary: Intelligible differentia (co-op vs others) with nexus to s.3 objects; distinguishes Ramanlal Nagardas where existing licensees discriminated against.

holdings.text: Impugned order violates Arts.14 and 19 by discriminatory administration creating monopoly via executive instructions not contemplated by cl.5.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that the impugned order is bad as violating the rights of the petitioner guaranteed under Arts. 14 and 19 of the Constitution. We must, therefore, quash the order of the licensing authority dated April 11, 1961.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Authority followed govt policy of monopoly to co-ops instead of independent application of cl.5; statewide exclusion of private dealers confirmed by affidavits.

holdings.text: Licensing authority must consider applications on merits per cl.5, ignoring instructions inconsistent with law.

anchor.surface_text: The licensing authority must now consider the application of the petitioner for a license for the year 1961 on merits along with the application of respondent No. 6 and such other applications as may be still pending.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act quasi-judicially per High Court directions; prior orders quashed for non-application of mind.

holdings.text: Executive instructions cannot override statutory provisions like cl.5; such method destroys rule of law.

anchor.surface_text: Such a method Will destroy the very basis of the rule of law and strike at the very root of orderly administration of law. We have thought it necessary to refer to this matter because we feel that the instructions...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Instructions for monopoly not in consonance with cl.5 preference; executive cannot supplant law.

holdings.text: Order dated April 11, 1961 and license to respondent No.6 quashed; fresh consideration directed.

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, quash the order of the licensing authority dated April 11, 1961. We must also quash the order by which the licensing authority granted a licence in favour of respondent No. 6.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Vitiated by Art.14/19 violation; remedy under Art.32.

precedents.case_name: Ramanlal Nagardas v. M. S. Palnitkar
precedents.cited_proposition: Classification for legislative objects must be founded on intelligible differentia having rational relation to the object sought to be achieved; entrusting wholesale distribution of sugar to co-operative societies excluding other dealers violates Art. 14
precedents.cited_holding: action of the State Government in entrusting wholesale distribution of sugar to co-operative societies to the exclusion of other licence-holders amounted to a discrimination which violated Art. 14

precedents.cited_proposition: Middlemans profits increase price; replace by co-operative societies

outcome.relief_summary: Impugned order dated April 11, 1961 quashed; order granting licence to respondent No. 6 quashed; licensing authority directed to consider petitioner's and other pending applications for 1961 licence on merits in accordance with cl. 5 of Control Order, 1961, ignoring inconsistent instructions.
directions: Licensing authority must consider applications on merits along with respondent No. 6's application.
Have regard to cl. 5 of Control Order, 1961 and relevant law in light of judgment observations.
Ignore instructions not in consonance with law.
Dispose of applications expeditiously as 1961 year ending soon.
